verses.text: The word of the LORD came to me, saying:
verses.comment: The prophetic formula stresses divine initiative. Ezekiel is serving as a mouthpiece of God. Compare also the consistent theme throughout Ezekiel of God speaking directly to and through His prophets.

verses.text: Son of man, set your face toward Jerusalem and preach against the sanctuaries. Prophesy against the land of Israel,
verses.comment: God defines the target of judgment: Jerusalem, especially its religious centers. 'Sanctuaries' refers to the temple and associated sites of worship.

verses.text: and say to the land of Israel, 'Thus says the LORD: Behold, I am against you, and I will draw my sword from its sheath and cut off from you both righteous and wicked.
verses.comment: God's 'sword' here symbolizes divine judgment. The sweeping nature of this judgment recalls the seriousness of sin and highlights God's holiness.

verses.text: Because I will cut off from you both righteous and wicked, therefore my sword shall go out from its sheath against all flesh from south to north;
verses.comment: Judgment is widespread, sparing no one. This anticipates Christ’s own words on judgment and the division at the final day (Matt. 13:49-50).

verses.text: So all flesh will know that I, the LORD, have drawn my sword from its sheath; it will not return again.
verses.comment: The Lord acts in full public view, ensuring His sovereignty is unmistakable. 'It will not return again' signals the certainty and finality of His decree, echoing prophetic permanence.

verses.text: Sigh therefore, son of man, with a breaking heart and with bitter grief. Sigh before their eyes.
verses.comment: The prophet is told to visibly mourn, signifying the seriousness of the coming judgment. The emotional display models godly sorrow, a call to repentance seen throughout Scripture.

verses.text: And when they say to you, ‘Why do you sigh?’ you shall say, ‘Because of the news that is coming. Every heart will melt, all hands will be feeble, every spirit will faint, and all knees will be weak as water.’ Behold, it is coming, and it will surely happen, declares the Lord GOD.
verses.comment: This language stresses the overwhelming fear and helplessness that will accompany God’s judgment. It prefigures the awe and trembling at the final Day of the Lord.

verses.text: The word of the LORD came to me again, saying:
verses.comment: A new oracle begins, structuring Ezekiel’s revelation in clear stages, akin to liturgical proclamation and repetition for emphasis.

verses.text: Son of man, prophesy and say, Thus says the Lord: Say, A sword, a sword is sharpened and also polished;
verses.comment: The sword’s preparation underlines the certainty and readiness of God’s judgment, reflecting His justice and holiness.

verses.text: sharpened to make a great slaughter, polished that it may flash like lightning! Shall we rejoice? You have despised the rod, the one who struck.
verses.comment: The question ‘Shall we rejoice?’ is rhetorical, indicating there is no cause for joy amidst impending judgment. The ‘rod’ refers to discipline, which they rejected.

verses.text: So the sword is handed over to be polished, to be placed into the hand of the slayer.
verses.comment: The ‘slayer’ symbolizes Babylon, God’s chosen instrument of judgment. In salvation history, God often works through secondary agents.

verses.text: Cry out and wail, son of man, for it will come against my people, against all the leaders of Israel. They will be delivered over to the sword together with my people. Therefore, strike your thigh!
verses.comment: ‘Strike your thigh’ is an ancient gesture of sorrow. Even leaders—shepherds—are not spared, highlighting the seriousness of sin in those who should lead faithfully.

verses.text: For the test is here; and what if even the rod that despises will be no more? declares the Lord GOD.
verses.comment: Judgment acts as a test, purging the unfaithful. The rod (God’s discipline) is itself set aside; a more terrible punishment looms, echoing Christ’s warnings of spiritual vigilance.

verses.text: Therefore, son of man, prophesy and clap your hands. Let the sword strike twice, yes, three times. It is the sword of the slain, the sword for the great slaughter, which surrounds them,
verses.comment: ‘Clap your hands’ is a prophetic sign-act. The repeated blows reflect the certainty and intensity of judgment—reminding of persistent calls to repentance before final judgment.

verses.text: so that hearts may melt, and many may stumble. I have set the sword against all their gates, that the flash of the sword may cut down their people. Ah! It is made like lightning, made ready for slaughter.
verses.comment: The sword ‘against all their gates’ points to inescapable judgment—a foreshadowing of the utter vulnerability before divine justice.

verses.text: Gather yourself, go to the right, set yourself to the left, wherever your edge is appointed.
verses.comment: Every direction, every side is included. None are outside God’s reach—recalling again the call to holiness and vigilance for the whole household of faith.

verses.text: I also will clap my hands, and I will satisfy my fury; I, the LORD, have spoken.
verses.comment: God’s action echoes the prophet’s sign-act, underscoring the seriousness of the coming judgment. His fury is not arbitrary but judicial, aiming to restore justice.

verses.text: The word of the LORD came to me again, saying:
verses.comment: A repeated prophetic introduction, emphasizing the “now and not yet” quality of biblical prophecy.

verses.text: As for you, son of man, mark out two ways for the sword of the king of Babylon to come. Both of them shall come from the same land. Mark a signpost; make it at the head of the way to a city.
verses.comment: The act of making a signpost signifies clarity of choice and consequence—echoing Scriptural themes of two ways (see Matt. 7:13-14).

verses.text: Mark a way for the sword to go to Rabbah of the Ammonites and to Judah, into fortified Jerusalem.
verses.comment: God’s justice extends to Gentile nations as well as to His own people. Judgment on Jerusalem is not a sign of abandonment, but a call to repentance and faithfulness.

verses.text: For the king of Babylon stands at the fork in the road, at the head of the two ways, to use divination. He shakes arrows, consults with idols, and looks at liver.
verses.comment: Shows the pagan king relying on superstition. God sovereignly uses even the vain efforts of nations to accomplish His purposes (Isa. 46:10).

verses.text: Into his right hand comes the divination for Jerusalem, to set up battering rams, to open the mouth for slaughter, to raise the battle cry, to set battering rams against the gates, to cast up siege ramps, to build a siege wall.
verses.comment: The direction is providentially set; Jerusalem is the target. Note the detailed description of siege warfare.

verses.text: But to them, it will seem like a false divination; they have sworn solemn oaths. But he brings their guilt to remembrance, that they may be captured.
verses.comment: Israel will dismiss the threat as groundless, but God ensures their guilt is not forgotten. Judgment is based on covenant unfaithfulness.

verses.text: Therefore thus says the Lord GOD: Because you have made your guilt to be remembered, in that your transgressions are uncovered, so that all your deeds are seen—because you have come to remembrance, you will be captured by the hand.
verses.comment: The unveiling of sin is a prerequisite for judgment, paralleling the biblical pattern of confession preceding divine justice (1 John 1:9).

verses.text: And you, O profane and wicked prince of Israel, whose day has come, in the time of final punishment,
verses.comment: 'Wicked prince' refers to King Zedekiah, the last king before Jerusalem’s fall. ‘Final punishment’ foreshadows the ultimate reckoning for all rulers.

verses.text: thus says the Lord GOD: Remove the turban and take off the crown. Things will not remain as they are. Exalt the low and bring low the exalted.
verses.comment: This is a dramatic transfer of authority—pointing to the humble being exalted, as in the Magnificat (Luke 1:52), a theme fulfilled in Christ the true King.

verses.text: A ruin, a ruin, a ruin I will make it. And it shall be no more, until he comes to whom the judgment belongs, and to him I will give it.
verses.comment: 'He comes to whom the judgment belongs' is a messianic prophecy, echoing Genesis 49:10 and setting the stage for Christ, who is the rightful King and Judge.

verses.text: And you, son of man, prophesy, and say, Thus says the Lord GOD concerning the Ammonites and their reproach; say, 'A sword, a sword is drawn for the slaughter, it is polished to consume, to flash like lightning—'
verses.comment: Ammon is indicted for mocking Israel. God extends His justice universally. The sword language maintains continuity, emphasizing God's control over nations.

verses.text: while they see for you false visions, while they divine lies for you—to lay you on the necks of the slain, of the wicked, whose day has come, in the time of final punishment.
verses.comment: Ammon’s false prophets are exposed, and their involvement in Israel’s downfall will not exempt them from God’s wrath.

verses.text: Return your sword to its sheath. In the place where you were created, in the land of your origin, I will judge you.
verses.comment: Ammon’s return to its own land suggests judgment ‘fitting the crime.’ God meets out justice with precision and completeness.

verses.text: I will pour out my indignation upon you; I will blow upon you with the fire of my wrath, and I will give you into the hands of brutal men, skillful to destroy.
verses.comment: Divine wrath is compared to fire, a frequent Scripture metaphor for purifying judgment and final reckoning (cf. Matt. 3:12).

verses.text: You shall be fuel for the fire; your blood shall be in the midst of the land. You shall be remembered no more, for I, the LORD, have spoken.
verses.comment: Finality is stressed—judicial oblivion is the fate of the unrepentant. Compare this with Christ’s teaching on eternal consequence and the call to remain in His covenant.
